div.l: Unhardy is vnsely thus men saith
And vp he roos and softely he wente
Vn to þe cradel and in his hand it hente
And bar it softe vn to his beddes feet
Sone after þe wyf hir routyng leet
And gan to wake and wente hir out to pisse
And com a geyn and gan hir cradel mysse
And groped here and there but sche fond noon
Allas qduod she almost I hadde misgoon
I hadde almost goon to þe clerkes bed
Ey benedicite þan had I foule ysped
And forth she gooth til she þe cradel fond
And gropeth alwey forther with hir hond
And fond þe bed and þouȝte not but good
By cause þᵗat þe cradel by it stood
And nyste where she was for it was derk
But faire ⁊and wel she crepte in to þe clerk
And lyth ful stille ⁊and wolde haue caught a sleep
Withynne a while þis Iohn þe clerk vp leep
And on þis goode wyf he leyth on sore
So mery a fitte ne hadde she nouȝt ful ȝore
He priketh harde / and depe as he were mad
This ioly lyf / han þise clerkes lad
Til þᵗat þe thridde cok bigan to synge
¶ Aleyn wax wery in the dawenynge
For he hadde swonken / al þe longe nyght
And saide farewel Malyn swete wight
The day is come I may no lenger byde
But eủere mo where so I go or ryde
I am þin owne clerk so haue I cele
Now deere lēmman qduod she go farewele
But or þou go oo þing I wol þe telle
Whan þᵗat þou wendest homward by þe mille
Right at þe entre / of þe dore behynde
Thow shalt a cake of half a busshell fynde
That was ymaked of thyn owne Mele
Which þat I halp my fader for to stele
And goode lemman / god þe saue and kepe
And with þᵗat worde / almost she gan to wepe
